question: Yep. It's here.
answer: We go out to dinner - we might never come back. I live...here.

question: Lieutenant Nunally, please. No. Thank you. I'll see him later.
answer: You're - home early.

question: I just felt a sudden urge.
answer: Are you...okay? Crawford shrugs, smiling strangely. He looks pained.

question: I could use a hug. Jennifer submits guiltily. Crawford embraces her, tight. She waits it out, until:
answer: Have you been drinking? He lets go and she steps back. Studying him. Scared.

question: I've been watching you sleep. At night.
answer: That's creepy.

question: Sometimes when I'm at work, I'll start thinking about you and I'll just get - just - overwhelmed.
answer: Tommy -

question: It's a dense, crushing - geophysical force. Like I'm pinned. At the core - where things change. You ever get that way about me, Jen?
answer: What are you talking about?

question: I'm trying to describe my feelings.
answer: Those don't sound like feelings.

question: No? What's the sound of one feeling...in a forest?
answer: You think you're so much smarter than I am. That must make you feel very powerful.

question: Helpless, actually. Silence.
answer: Okay. Maybe it's time to really talk.

question: No.
answer: No? He shakes his head. Frayed and worn, she sighs. Fine. Whatever. I'll make you some dinner. He watches her turn and head for the kitchen. To her back:

question: I know. Everything. She stops, exhales. Looking down. Afraid. Grateful it's happening at last.
answer: I'm so sorry.

question: Everybody just LEAVE US ALONE! He calmly aims up at the frosted-glass transom and fires three times - watching Gifford fling himself away. Crawford collects the shell casings, wipes them, drops them back on the floor. Peeling off the rubber gloves, he crosses to the fireplace and throws them into the flames. They curl and blacken.
answer: Yeah. What do we know?

question: Yes?
answer: Mr. Crawford?

question: Who is this?
answer: My name is Lieutenant Robert Nunally. I'm a hostage negotiator for the Los - Crawford hangs up. Thoughtful. Mr. Crawford? Nunally grimaces, shuts his phone, shaking his head. But then he turns - with the SWAT Commander and everyone else - - as Crawford's front door unlocks and opens a few inches. Nunally considers this, looks at the SWAT COMMANDER. Okay then. Here we go. He pulls his suit jacket back on, then reaches into the trunk for his back-up gun. He tucks it into the back of his belt, concealed under the jacket. He takes a walkie-talkie and starts for the house. The spectators fall silent. Radios crackle and hiss as he heads up the driveway. Mr. Crawford? The door pushes open very slowly. Nunally stays in the doorway. Hey. Crawford studies him, staying back.

question: Get rid of the vampires. Nunally is confused; Crawford gestures at the flood-lit lawn outside. Nunally glances back, sees the SWAT teams and - down the street - the distant barricades, the media. He nods, steps in and lets the door shut. Careful silence. Do I call you Rob?
answer: If you want.

question: Not vampires.
answer: What?

question: Not vampires. Ghouls. Sorry. Nunally nods, humoring him, glancing around. Sees the small pool of blood where Jennifer fell. Plays it cool.
answer: Mr. Crawford, what do you say you give me the gun - so I can pay more attention to what you're saying? Crawford sighs.

question: Is that your best shot? So to speak.
answer: I just think - maybe it would -

question: Tell you what We both put down our guns. At the same time. Crawford gestures to a chair across the room - by the foyer door, near Nunally. We set them down and step away. Then you can "pay more attention" to what I'm saying. Nunally studies Crawford...and the gun, hovering above the coffee table. Looking for a trick, a catch. But there isn't one. If Crawford sets down his gun and steps away, he'll be standing in the open center of the room. Happy ending, then. Nunally stares Crawford in the eyes - - then slowly takes his gun from his shoulder holster. Eyes on each other from across the room - moving very slowly - the two men cautiously set down their guns - - and step away. Crawford smiles. Nunally smiles, too, reassuring and false. Begins to edge forward - alert to the possibility of a lunge for the gun or having another weapon. But Crawford stays absolutely still.
answer: Mr. Crawford, your neighbor mentioned that your wife -

question: It's Tom.
answer: I'm sorry?

question: You can call me Tom.
answer: Tom. Your wife. Is she here?

question: Yes. Crawford gestures to a library alcove, behind him, out of view.
answer: Is she all right? Nunally begins to drift slowly to the side, to see.

question: I don't think she is. I shot her, Rob. Nunally's nodding, edging to look into the alcove -
answer: You shot your wife.

question: It was like I just suddenly - snapped. We were arguing - and I got the gun.
answer: - okay - I hear you -

question: And I shot her in the head. I know it was wrong. Are you listening to me? But Nunally is not. He's frozen - staring, shocked, at the back wall of the alcove - which he can now see. There's a big framed black-white photograph
answer: Oh Jesus Christ. Nunally fumbles for his walkie-talkie, rushing past Crawford toward the alcove - - kneeling by Jennifer, who lies, face-up in a red puddle - We need a medic in here! Get the ambulance up! RIGHT NOW! NOW! NOW! Nunally feels her neck frantically for a pulse - looking in her open, vacant eyes for some sign - Oh no - God no - I can't - get a - Nunally desperately starts C.P.R., his hands getting bloody. He stops to check her neck for a pulse now and then - - as Crawford slowly approaches from the living room, standing behind Nunally. Cold.

question: You know, I think I read somewhere that a good place to find a pulse is the femoral artery. It's on the inner surface of the upper thigh. If you put your fingers - you know, right up inside her dress -
answer: Yeah. I'm good. To avoid talking more, he heads out to the glaring lights and chaos outside.

question: Mrs. Demello? MRS. DEMELLO! Your CAR! Silence. He sighs. Shuts the door and presses a button near the light-switch. There's mechanical grinding noise as the far wall slowly rolls up, letting in daylight and revealing an alley beyond the hanging clothes and cinderblock shelves. He presses the garage-door-opener button again, and hurries across the apartment to duck out under the closing door. Come on, Phil I'm not knocking it down to a Class C. My backlog of open cases does not mitigate the fact that your client tried to kill his brother-in-law with - oh, right, a "golfing accident"? Your client owns one golf club and no golf Well, I won't see you in court, but someone from this office will. You take it up with them, I gotta go. Willy Slocum. Oh - hey, hi, yes. Assistant District Attorney NORMAN CHANG throws the door open without looking:
answer: Wooton Sims?! Willy holds up a finger, talking into his cell:

question: No, I didn't. Wow. Okay. Norman mouths "WOOTON SIMS?!" repeatedly during: No - short notice is...fine. No, I can. Black tie. Sure. What time? Okay. Yes. Thank her. He hangs up, exhales slowly. Looks at Norman.
answer: Wooton - SIMS?! Wooton Sims?!

question: Please stop saying, "Wooton Sims" over and over. It's starting to sound like nonsense words.
answer: You asshole!

question: Okay
answer: How the hell did you get a job at Wooton Sims?! I can't even get an interview! I've been here five years. I'm your supervisor. I graduated USC, summa!

question: We're just going to pretend he's not talking, okay? I'm really jammed-up all day, and I need to rent a tuxedo - for tonight.
answer: A tuxedo?! Oh, come on! You are so full of shit.

question: William No-Middle-Initial Slocum.
answer: Yes sir.

question: Sit. Eighty-four-percent conviction rate. That's remarkable.
answer: Thank you.

question: With a case load thirty percent higher than any other first-year DDA. Of course - you also swapped more cases than the rest of them put together. Willy considers his options. He always does.
answer: I offered my losing cases in exchange for two or three of anyone else's possible convictions. They couldn't handle their workloads, and I prefer not to lose. Lobruto knew this; the question was would Willy admit it.

question: You're going to need a middle initial.
answer: Sir?

question: You're going to Wooton Sims.
answer: In two weeks.

question: You'll be able to afford a better suit. But those guys all play squash and have middle names. They go in for the mother's maiden name a lot. Beat. Willy doesn't like the implied personal judgement, but the only way it shows is how calm he stays.
answer: My mother didn't have a maiden name. Lobruto nods, unruffled by Willy's hard calm.

question: So you're a bastard; sometimes I can be a son-of-a-bitch. Maybe you belong here.
answer: I didn't work this hard to stay where I belong.

question: You're a street-fighter, Willy. You should be in court. We can move you up to better cases.
answer: I appreciate the offer.

question: I didn't think so. Well - you got your litigation experience. Your chops. And your juicy private sector job. Anything else the City of Los Angeles can do for you? Willy's amused. He stands, too. As they shake hands:
answer: No, I think that's everything - thank you.

question: The offer stands. If you get tired of carrying a spear. Willy nods - but Lobruto notes the tiny flicker in his eyes It's an opera joke. Give my regards to Bob.
answer: Willy Slocum.

question: Willy Slocum.
answer: I've got an Attempted Homicide. Conley caught it last night, but he's hung up in motions with Gardner. Arraignment in Part Seven, at three o'clock.

question: Three o'clock is in fifteen minutes.
answer: Thank you. What's the temperature?

question: I can't do it.
answer: You do still actually work here, Willy, right? I mean, you're still going to be cashing your paycheck for another two weeks and everything?

question: Just get somebody else for this one.
answer: Everybody's booked up. Look

question: A real confession?
answer: Spontaneous and signed. Come on, Willy. Willy sighs. Looking down at his coffee-soaked suit.

question: Okay. Here's the problem.
answer: You know - I really wish I was going to see this.

question: Mr. Slocum. Nice to see a man who dresses for court.
answer: Sorry, your honor. Long story. Willy, hurrying to Prosecution Table, barely glances at the Defense Table - - but Crawford, sitting beside his PUBLIC DEFENDER in an orange jumpsuit and handcuffs, never takes his eyes off Willy, intrigued.

question: Grapevine has it the punch-line is Wooton Sims.
answer: Yes, ma'am.

question: Good for you, double-oh-seven. Let's see what public service is offering you by way of a send-off: And do you wish to enter a plea at this time?
answer: Not guilty. But I also want to waive my right to counsel, and represent myself. Willy looks up from the file - startled.

question: Do you have a problem with your appointed counsel, Mr. Crawford?
answer: No. I just want to do it myself. I believe it's within my rights. I'm not your client. Try and keep up, would you? The P.D. shuts up, taken aback. The Judge considers Crawford, thoughtful, then turns to Willy.

question: Mr. Slocum? He likes you.
answer: Terrific.

question: Mr. Crawford seems to understand his rights and responsibilities.
answer: All due respect, your honor, I'm worried this may turn into some sort of a - circus -

question: Sure. Why not. Crawford smiles at him, as the Judge opens her calendar.
answer: You're supposed to be good. Willy takes him in - wary, seeing an edge of anger and fear beneath the tough controlled cop manner.

question: Is that what I'm supposed to be?
answer: I asked around. You're supposed to be top-notch - but to me it looks like you've got one foot out the door, and you're wiping the rest of us off the bottom of the other one.

question: I'm sorry to...disappoint you. Nunally is silent - frustrated. The concrete walls and ceilings echo from distant cars.
answer: I took Crawford's confession.

question: And now you want mine?
answer: I'm here to warn you. Take this seriously, because it's serious. This guy is stone cold - and his wife - is lying in a hospital bed - with brain damage... He struggles to keep himself under control.

question: Are you all right?
answer: Are you gonna be on this, or what?

question: Yeah. I'm on it. You got a confession. You took the gun out of his hand. It's done.
answer: I'm just - telling you. Is that okay? Or are you too friggin' busy?!

question: No. It's okay. Willy waits. Watching the tortured cop wrestle with demons.
answer: Forget it. It's a lock. We're good. Put him down. Bury him. Willy nods. Nunally turns and walks away, down a ramp. Willy watches him go. Sad. Like he's watching Nunally drown. But he's seen people drown before...and he's not about to put out a hand. Might get pulled in himself.

question: Are you a shark?
answer: Sorry?

question: You've been circling the lobby for half-an-hour now, like if you stopped you'd die.
answer: If I stopped, I'd be standing around with no one to talk to. At which point, death would be a relief.

question: Why don't you talk to Bob? Willy stops walking, getting a little careful.
answer: "Bob" is talking to the Governor. Do I know you? She puts a hand out, gently amused.

question: Nikki Gardner. Senior Associate, Wooton Sims.
answer: Oh - hey, hi. It was your office that called, with the invitation.

question: On Bob's orders.
answer: Listen, I don't...actually know "Bob." I mean, I've only met the man once. Nikki nods, considering this. And him.

question: Interesting. They're each conscious of an unexpected buzz of attraction. The lobby lights flicker, breaking the spell a little. As the CROWD begins to drift toward the auditorium doors: You like opera?
answer: Truth is, I haven't really had that much expos-

question: Neither do I. With a conspiratorial head-tip, Nikki moves toward the plaza doors. Willy follows. Bob assigned you to my team. I'll supervise your case-work, steer you through the office arcana, and generally keep an eye on you.
answer: Kind of like a mentor.

question: Kind of like a probation officer. Beat. Willy nods, meeting Nikki's gaze as she looks to make sure he's got it.
answer: Okay.

question: Wooton Sims expects absolute loyalty and a hundred-and-ten-percent performance. But
answer: You're trying to scare me.

question: Yes.
answer: You're going to have to try harder. She stops walking. Studying Willy.

question: Can I ask you something personal?
answer: Sure.

question: Who are you? Willy doesn't answer. Maybe uncertain what she means. Maybe not wanting her to know. Or even not knowing, himself. We have a guy in our criminal division, fresh out of Yale, named Calvin Tyler. One of our very rich clients gets pulled over, D.U.I. - which is routine bullshit, so Calvin gets it. Against you. Next thing we know, Calvin is fired, and Bob Wooton, who has never even interviewed a junior associate before - let alone hired one - says you're on my team. Willy weighs his options. Decides to level:
answer: It was a good bust, so Calvin came to me for a deal. I told him if he could arrange an interview for me with Mr. Wooton, I would throw the case. I laid out his arguments and evidence for him - and I showed him how I would lose. Calvin set up my appointment for the day after our court date. Then he did what I had suggested in court - and I wiped the floor with him. Your client got the maximum. Next day, I met with Mr. Wooton. Bob. Beat.

question: Wow. You know what's brilliant about that?
answer: Yes.

question: You didn't actually do anything all that wrong.
answer: Well - I wasn't entirely honest with Calvin. His cell-phone rings. He ignores it.

question: You gonna get that?
answer: Everyone I need to talk to is here. They are both feeling the electricity in the air between them. They wait the phone out, enjoying the forbidden insanity of it. But then:

question: We need to talk about your transition timetable.
answer: All right.

question: Bob believes in trial-by-fire. He wants you up-to-speed two weeks from Tuesday, because we're getting on a plane to Chicago for depositions in a class-action against our biggest client, Armstead Pharmaceutical.
answer: No problem. She studies Willy, trying to make sure he understands:

question: That's catch-up on three years' work - and you haven't closed out your old job yet.
answer: I'm good at trials. Even by fire. Beat.

question: You know, a little bit of fear can be a very healthy thing to have.
answer: I'm looking forward to when I can afford the luxury of having some. Nikki sighs, smiles. Enjoying him, somewhat reluctantly.

question: I'll have them put the Armstead materials in your new office.
answer: Thanks. Boss. He watches her head off into the night. He remains, alone, in his tuxedo, looking at the elegant glittering arts plaza. Then he checks his cell-phone. Dials.

question: Thanks. Boss. He watches her head off into the night. He remains, alone, in his tuxedo, looking at the elegant glittering arts plaza. Then he checks his cell-phone. Dials.
answer: Marchand.

question: It's Willy Slocum. What's up?
answer: Your gun in that Palisades shooting is no good.

question: How can the gun be "no good"?
answer: It's a perfectly good weapon. A Heckler & Koch nine-millimeter. It's just no good as evidence. It's never been fired.

question: It's the gun from the scene?
answer: Yep. Bought by Mr. Thomas Crawford and registered to his wife, about a month ago. Apparently a gift.

question: And between the shooting and arrest, this guy was locked inside his house.
answer: Is that a question?

question: No, I mean, just
answer: Do you have a question I can answer? Beat. Willy shakes the puzzle off, irritated:

question: Look, our weapon is in that house somewhere. Get a team out to search it tomorrow morning.
answer: Ya think?

question: Thank you. He shuts the phone. Takes a moment, looking around again at where he is. Absently tugs at his tie and vest, lets the case go. Heads in to the opera. Yeah. The idea here is we're trying to take boxes out - not bring more in. Whoa - wait a second, this is a screw- up. I already have these documents. I sent this box
answer: Marchand.

question: Where are we on this gun?
answer: We can't find it, Willy.

question: I'm in trial on Monday.
answer: I know. I don't know what to tell you. I'm there now.

question: You said you'd get a team out a week ago -
answer: I'm here now. My team has been here twice already. Do you really need it?

question: Do I need it?! The weapon?! He takes a second. Sighs, exasperated - but honest: I don't know. Probably not. Defendant's a whack-job.
answer: He went pro se, right?

question: Yeah. Just when you think they're not really stupid, they defend themselves.
answer: You've got a confession and an airtight bunch of circumstantial. We've gone over this place top-to- bottom three times now, Willy. Willy takes a breath. Thinks it through.

question: Yeah, okay. Don't worry about it. Sorry - got a lot going on.
answer: Must be rough, figuring out what you're gonna do with all that money.

question: Hey, I had to sit through an opera last week.
answer: Oh gee - lemme see if I can express how much sympathy I have

question: How's my wife?
answer: I don't know.

question: I heard somewhere, I think it was on N.P.R., that you're supposed to talk to people in a coma. Play their favorite music. Supposedly it reaches them. Willy, now ready, lets Crawford study him. You represent Jennifer. The voice of the victim, judicially speaking. But you haven't gone to see her?
answer: Not yet.

question: Too busy getting up to speed on Armstead Pharmaceutical? Beat.
answer: I beg your pardon?

question: I'm not judging you. I think anyone - coming from...what you came from - then paying your way through East-Okie Cowshit College and Tulsa Law by writing papers for Princeton kids on the internet - my God, it must have eaten your liver! Sixty-thousand dollars in debt, eighty-four percent conviction rate
answer: What the hell have you been doing.

question: I'm permitted the use of a private investigator.
answer: Not to investigate me!

question: Why not? You're investigating me.
answer: You shot your wife.

question: Allegedly. That's how it works, right? If I can't introduce something in court as evidence - it doesn't exist. Legally.
answer: Look - I don't want to play games with you.

question: I'm afraid you have to.
answer: Is this some form of - communication?

question: You sent me a box of papers.
answer: It's called Discovery. The State has a legal obliga-

question: There's nothing in it, Willy. You haven't 'discovered' anything. Have you found the gun? Beat.
answer: Not yet.

question: No. Does it bother you that I call you Willy?
answer: No. Crawford nods. Pleased. Leans forward.

question: I'd like you to consider becoming my lawyer. I'll pay you. A lot of money.
answer: I'm - prosecuting you.

question: Yeah, but I'm offering you a chance to get on the right side of this whole mess while you still can.
answer: Are you out of your mind?

question: I think - on advice of counsel - I'll decline to answer that one. Willy studies him. Decides
answer: I don't need the gun to convict you, by the way.

question: She was cheating, you know. Willy looks at him, slightly taken aback. He didn't know; it wasn't in the confession. As he considers whether it makes a difference - he notices Crawford watching, enjoying. Willy shuts his briefcase.
answer: It doesn't matter what she did...Tom. What you did is a crime.

question: Perhaps. But - maybe my so-called peers will look at me and see themselves. Betrayed. Frustrated. Humiliated. And you and I both know, Willy, that people have an infinite capacity for believing in their own innocence.
answer: Great. Take the stand. Tell your story. I'd appreciate it.

question: Not to mention the fact you have no actual evidence connecting me to the crime. Willy smiles, gets up.
answer: Except your confession. Crawford watches him go to the door.

question: My grandfather was an egg farmer. Willy stops, annoyed.
answer: Is this gonna be about how you had a rough childhood?

question: I used to candle eggs at his farm. You know what that is? You hold an egg up to a light, and look for imperfections. The first time I did it, he told me to put the ones that were cracked or flawed in a bucket - for the bakery. He came back an hour later and there were three hundred eggs in the bakery bucket. He asked me what the hell I was doing. I found a flaw in every single one. Thin places in the shell, minuscule cracks. Look closely enough and you'll find everything has a weak spot...where it can break.
answer: Looking for mine?

question: No, I've found yours.
answer: Illuminate me. Crawford considers how to put it.

question: You're a winner, Willy. Silence. Willy pushes the call-button by the door.
answer: Huh. Well. Joke's on me then, I guess.

question: Yes. It is.
answer: I'll see you in court, Mr. Crawford.

question: I'll see you in court, Mr. Crawford.
answer: Make sure you sign the one with the devil in blood. It's not binding otherwise. He looks up, smiles.

question: Just want to be ready for Chicago. I'm all closed-out, downtown. Last trial starts Monday. Beat. Not pleased:
answer: You've got a trial Monday?

question: Yeah
answer: That gives you three days. You told me - and I told Bob - that you would be ready to hit the ground r-

question: The man confessed. And he's pro se.
answer: Willy, some but acting as his own lawyer - he could drag it out for months!

question: You want to hear his witness list? Nikki nods. Willy is silent. She frowns.
answer: No witnesses? Willy leans in, enjoying this part - analyzing, even admiring, Crawford's ploy:

question: It's kind of clever
answer: You're gonna miss being in court, aren't you? He studies her, confident. Gestures to the stacks of Armstead materials:

question: I'm almost halfway through these. And I think I've already found about six disqualifiers in Delaware, Ohio, and Florida. I have to check case law in each state, but it looks good. I'll get the rest done over the long weekend. Nikki sighs, smiles a little, against her will. He's won her over...again. Willy shrugs, grins. In the silence, the impossible electricity returns. After a moment - to defuse it:
answer: You don't go home for Thanksgiving? Slight beat.

question: No. She studies him a moment, thoughtful. Careful.
answer: If you want - you're welcome at mine. My family's.

question: Really? She nods. Smiling a little, knowing her family and starting to know Willy:
answer: I think it would be interesting. Beat.

question: Yeah. Okay, thank you.
answer: Cool. Beat. She leaves. Willy doesn't go back to work right away.

question: Thank you, Dr. Kang. Crawford tears off the page, starts another. So after you put down your gun, what did Mr. Crawford do?
answer: He confessed to shooting his wife.

question: He confessed. Did Mr. Crawford appear confused or in any way intoxicated, impaired?
answer: No. Not at all. He knew what was going on.

question: What did Mr. Crawford say? Nunally looks at Crawford, enjoying the fatal blow:
answer: He said, "I got the gun and I shot my wife. God help me, I shot her in the head. I know it was wrong."

question: Objection. Everyone turns, surprised.
answer: I'm sorry - Mr. Crawford, did you say something? Crawford sets aside his pen for the first time. Looks up.

question: Yes. I want to object.
answer: On what grounds?

question: I don't know what you'd call it. They - it wasn't the first time, either, but - I don't know the legal term.
answer: Why don't you just explain it in layman's terms.

question: Fucking the victim. Uproar in the court.
answer: Mr. Crawford -

question: You said layman's terms -
answer: Your honor -

question: I'm sorry - what would you call it - legally - when the officer who arrested you has been having sexual intercourse with your wife? Utter silence. Willy whirls a look at Nunally. The cop meets his eyes - a deer in headlights.
answer: Oh - shit.

question: I think it's objectionable - maybe I'm wrong.
answer: Your honor...

question: Willy Slocum.
answer: Well - you've gotta admire the cleverness of it. Willy begins cutting open the package as he talks:

question: Do I?
answer: Come on, Willy - give the devil his due.

question: Yeah. I'm just trying to figure out what that is.
answer: Okay

question: No.
answer: Well, he pretty much has to if he's gonna save any face. So here's the strategy

question: I let him?
answer: Yeah, damage control. Stop getting your face on TV. As it is, I had to talk Bob down from cancelling your contract. But we've got to move fast and get out from under. Otherwise, and I quote

question: I can't just - walk away.
answer: Willy

question: I guess...that would be the smart way of looking at it.
answer: You want to come out and get drunk?

question: No. Thank you. I've got some stuff to take care of.
answer: All right. Don't beat yourself up.

question: I won't. He hangs up. Considering the empty eggshell. But then he looks up
answer: You don't look into who the victim was sleeping with? Willy burns, ashamed. But unable to admit it.

question: He - threw me off. Look, Crawford knew he'd be the prime suspect, so he gave us everything - but he made it all radioactive. The night this went down, it was over.
answer: But you still walked it into court, Willy. We might not have a case...but it didn't have to be a public humiliation for this office and the police department. Silence.

question: Are you taking me off?
answer: You're leaving anyway.

question: I'm starting to get a sense of this guy.
answer: That's not new evidence.

question: I can take him now
answer: It's not about you, Willy.

question: Yeah, it is. He made it that way. He likes me.
answer: What is that - some kind of Oklahoma insult?

question: Let me do this. I won't make you look bad. Beat.
answer: No. You won't. That's what I need to make sure you understand. I remove you now

question: If I lose.
answer: What?

question: You said "when." Lobruto grimaces. He shakes his head. Sighs.
answer: All right. It's yours. Willy nods. Stubborn. Scared.

question: You're not easy to find. I had to call Internal Affairs.
answer: Yeah - they put me on a desk - 'til this gets...sorted out. He uncomfortably watches Willy glance around at the half- empty liquor bottle, the mismatched suitcases and paper bags full of balled-up clothes. And the gun on the bed. Got home - my wife already took the kids to her folks. Press is all over our front lawn. Friggin' vampires. He falters, haunted by the echo. Willy doesn't notice:

question: What the hell were you thinking. You're on the job and you get called to your girlfriend's house -
answer: I didn't know it was her house. I'd never been there.

question: It was her name!
answer: I didn't know her name! Willy waits. Nunally explains, reluctant to expose himself: No last names. Her rules. We met at the same hotel room, twice a week - no phone calls, no questions. She didn't want us to know too much about each other. She said it was like...travel in a foreign country. No baggage - from our lives. Just us. Escaping.

question: Did you get the feeling she had rules because she had done it before? With other guys?
answer: No. I don't know. Maybe. No. It was all just this...crazy thing. For both of us. It was... real. You know? We didn't expect that, when we started. We didn't know where it was going. I had cheated so many times, I was numb - but she was ...new. And she made me feel like there was - some chance. To change. We were scared. It was like we were afraid to go forward, but we couldn't go back. You always think you have time. To work it out. Or make things right. What was I supposed to do?!

question: You were supposed to tell me!
answer: I'm married! I have kids!

question: You thought nobody knew - so maybe you could just walk away clean.
answer: No! I didn't think HE knew! OKAY?! Even - after. I thought it was just - massively fouled-up...bad luck. Like - God - telling me - something. I'm there. My mind is going crazy. I know the confession won't hold if anyone finds out. I thought the guy was a whack!

question: Yeah? Well, he's not. Nunally won't look at Willy. He just sits there, numb. Is there anything else you can give me. Anything that might get us some evidence. Nunally shakes his head. Willy grimaces. Goes to the door.
answer: I...tried to warn you. Willy stops. Looks back.

question: You warned me he was smart. You didn't warn me you were stupid. Nunally winces. Takes it. Willy feels a little badly. Two guys in a shabby motel room, in terrible trouble.
answer: How do we get the confession back in?

question: We don't.
answer: What are you gonna do? Willy shakes his head. Walks out.

question: Shake the boxes. The cereal boxes - shake 'em. And there's a chicken in the freezer. Thaw it out, check inside. The Deputy stares like he's nuts. Willy doesn't blink. The Deputy goes to shake the boxes, eyes on Willy The garage? Washer-dryer?
answer: And the tool shed, and the roof, and the H.V.A.C. ducts.

question: What about the door frames? The floors?
answer: What did he do

question: What about the neighbors' property? He could have thrown it over the hedges.
answer: We checked. He might have passed it off to somebody, Willy. Had an accomplice, waiting, out the back. Willy shakes his head, grim. Pacing.

question: This isn't an accomplice sort of guy. He slows. Looking across the room at the big Rube Goldberg device. As he moves toward it: This is a...guy who likes to show off. He examines the intricate workings, eyes travelling the clutter of metal and wires and motors. Checks Marchand - who shakes his head. You sure?
answer: I'm sure. Willy grimaces. Fuming, relentless:

question: It's a physical object. It can't just vanish. We're missing something - some step in the story. He begins walking through the crime, "the stations of the cross" - re-enacting it, starting from the front door, methodical, reciting it to himself: The neighbor sees her get home. He's already inside. She lets herself in. A minute or two later Boom. As Willy goes to where Jennifer fell:
answer: But then he carries her back there. Why? Willy walks along the path defined by the drops of blood:

question: Because he's gonna need time. To confess. When she's alone with the cop. Willy stops in the alcove, looking down at the dried blood, the discarded paramedic-supply-wrappers.
answer: Neighbor comes to the door. Willy nods, comes out - crosses to the foyer:

question: Crawford shouts, "Leave us alone" and fires three more rounds
answer: So everybody knows he's dangerous - and she might still be alive.

question: So they'll call the Negotiator. Now he's got about ten minutes. And that's it. He stands there with the imaginary gun in his hand. Looking around. Trying to think like Crawford. He can't.
answer: I'm sorry, Willy. Willy won't respond - because accepting the apology means admitting he's got nothing left.

question: Do you dare stay out? Do you dare go in? Studying framed photos And IF you go in - Should you turn left or right? Or right and three-quarters? Or maybe not quite. You can get so confused that you'll start in to race, Down long wiggled roads at break- necking pace No longer really looking for the gun. He's looking for insight. Contact. A way in. And grind on for miles across weirdish wild space, Headed I fear, toward a most useless place. He idly surveys the vanity, cluttered with cosmetics, skin- care products. Lifts her perfume, sniffs. The Waiting Place... For people just waiting. Waiting for a train to go Or a bus to come, or a plane to go Notices a storage box on the floor, left partly-open in the search. He shifts the lid aside. Or the mail to come, or the rain to go Or the phone to ring, or the snow to snow A high-school yearbook. An old photo album. A teddy bear. A snow-globe. A well-worn book by Dr. Seuss. Or waiting around for a Yes or No Or waiting for their hair to grow. Everyone is just waiting. Willy stares down at the souvenirs of a lost life. Waiting for the fish to bite Or waiting for wind to fly a kite Or waiting around for Friday night Or waiting perhaps for their Uncle Jake Jennifer Crawford lies with her head wrapped in gauze, eyes shut, plastic tubing down her throat held in place with tape. Willy sits beside her bed, reading Dr. Seuss: Or a pot to boil, or a Better Break Or a string of pearls, or a pair of pants Or a wig with curls... Or Another Chance. He stops reading a moment. Watching her:
answer: What are you doing? Willy turns. A work-weary RESIDENT comes past him to check the I.V.'s and monitors. He's about Willy's age.

question: I heard it might - help - if somebody talked to her.
answer: Who told you that?

question: The man who shot her. The RESIDENT looks up at Willy - who shrugs, uncomfortable. Is there any chance...she might come out of this?
answer: Are you a member of the family?

question: Sorry. I'm with the District Attorney's office. We don't have any other witnesses.
answer: This woman had a bullet plow through her brain.

question: I know. But you hear about people waking up from comas. After everybody said pull the plug - they wake up. You hear stuff like that all the time.
answer: You hear about Elvis and Aliens, too. All the time.

question: It's not impossible, though. Is it? I mean - why else are you keeping her like this? Beat. The Resident sighs.
answer: No. It's not impossible. But even if she did, she might not remember how to talk - let alone anything about how she was shot.

question: When I was here alone before, she moved a little.
answer: Are you just going to keep asking the same question in different ways until you hear the answer you want? Beat.

question: That's how it works with the law.
answer: I knew I should have gone to law school. Willy watches the Resident go out. Then he looks back down at Jennifer. Listening to the machines.

question: So this is all exactly how he left it. And he was - distraught. But he was working on this. He stands over unfinished Rube Goldberg device. Tools laid out on the work table - meticulous, organized. All distraught and everything. It's not evidence. Tell him I said no thank you. How long do you keep the tapes? Can I get a copy of October 9th? I'm kind of under the gun here. Right. Okay.
answer: White or dark, Willy?

question: Anything is fine, your honor.
answer: I'm off-duty, you can call me Lew. While Gardner piles turkey on a plate and passes it:

question: I don't mind; I get this kind of thing now and then. Almost always from people with money.
answer: Appearances can be deceiving, Willy. I grew up with eight brothers and sisters on a farm up in Fresno, and I promise you I saw my share of hard times. Willy considers his options.

question: My mom OD'd fairly frequently, so they put me in a Group Home. My younger sister is dead and my older brother is doing twenty-five-to-life.
answer: You win. Beat. Willy looks down, begins to eat again.

question: I usually do.
answer: Yes. I see that.

question: I wasn't. Nikki looks at Willy.
answer: What?

question: Taken off.
answer: That...doesn't make any sense. Lobruto has to do some kind of damage control -

question: I asked him not to. Silence. Nikki is staring at him. Angry.
answer: You are really stupid, did you know that? Willy doesn't know how to handle this; everyone else tries to be polite, eating and pretending not to notice.

question: I'm - getting new evidence -
answer: Where? The Evidence Store?! Oh, that's right - they open early the day after Thanksgiving. You're gonna be fine!

question: Did it ever occur to you I might be good enough to still win?!
answer: Who cares?! Win what?

question: The man shot his -
answer: You wanted corporate, right?! You wanted to play in the big leagues?!

question: Yeah, I'm just -
answer: You go to all that trouble getting yourself in - and then you just pay no attention to wh-

question: Look - I'm sorry - can we not talk about this here?! Nikki stops. Refusing to look around. Ashamed at losing control, turns back to her food:
answer: Fine.

question: Thank you. Everyone eats in silence a moment - then Nikki tosses down her napkin:
answer: I need to talk with you. She gets up and walks out of the room. With an awkward glance around, Willy excuses himself and follows her.

question: Look, I'm sorry I didn't tell you -
answer: Did you hear me, when I said Bob wanted you gone as soon as this thing broke?! Did you hear me say I went out on a limb to convince him -

question: Wouldn't it be better than damage control if I actually turn it around?
answer: And what if you don't? Willy has no answer. He doesn't think that way. And she sees that. She sees a young man from Oklahoma, in way over his head. Desperate to get through: You don't get it at all, do you?! You pulled a stunt to get yourself this job. Fine

question: What am I supposed to do?
answer: We told the man you're getting on a plane to Chicago, Tuesday. Painful silence.

question: Yeah. Okay. Nikki watches him dealing with it, sympathetic. The impossible feelings always running under the surface for them have developed a darker, aching tone. If anything, stronger. I think maybe I'm gonna go now.
answer: All right. Call if you want. He nods. Neither one moves. Judge Gardner enters cautiously from the dining room - breaking the spell. Nikki nods goodbye to Willy, and goes out quickly without meeting her father's eye. Awkward pause.

question: Shit! - by Nunally, on the other side of the glass. Catching his breath, Willy stares. He unlocks the French doors and Nunally steps in, uneasy, haggard. The hell are you doing here? Nunally looks around - taking a pint bottle from his overcoat pocket, uncapping it.
answer: We need to talk. He drinks, then offers the bottle. Willy hesitates, takes it. As he drinks: We have to find the gun. Willy winces at the liquor and the remark, hands back the bottle.

question: Thank you, Professor Einstein. It would also be good to find a couple of
answer: No - Willy

question: I've had three different teams here -
answer: He didn't leave between the shooting and when we took him out in cuffs. The gun is here. So we have to find it.

question: Well - we can't! You want to move on? Nunally tosses something from an inside pocket of the coat - - Willy catches it. A Heckler & Koch nine-millimeter in a plastic bag. Willy stares down at it. Then at Nunally, who holds up
answer: There's a guy in the Evidence Room, owes me a favor. Well - it's not so much a favor as I know stuff about him. He can trade this for the bullet from Jennifer, give us a ballistic match. Beat.

question: It's a crime.
answer: So who's gonna get away with a crime - this asshole, or us? Willy sighs. Tosses the gun back.

question: Go home.
answer: What else have you got?!

question: I'll find a way.
answer: No you won't. Willy watches Nunally stalk out through the big, strangely- lit room. The front door opens, and slams. A little worried, Willy takes a deep breath. Gets to work. He still has three days to break this open. Walking through the crime again. Playing it out in his mind. Standing in different places, getting different perspectives. Willy stands in the alcove. Looking around. There's something here. But he can't get it. His eye falls on the Rube Goldberg device. Moves closer, peering into the mechanism. Turns away

question: Willy. There's nothing here. Willy has barely slept all weekend. He shakes his head, reviewing the hotel surveillance tapes on a VCR/TV, stubborn.
answer: Guns don't just walk out of crime scenes. Marchand waves copies of Crawford's evidence - stills printed from home-video Dick took at a hostage negotiation

question: Two months before he shot his wife, this guy had his investigator watching the cop at work. He knew exactly how it would go down - and he didn't leave any loose ends.
answer: Then what is this Hotel surveillance. From that day. He was there. Why? Marchand watches over Willy's shoulder. Shrugs.

question: Had to see it for himself.
answer: See what? They were out at the pool.

question: The unmade bed. Her panties. Man's gonna shoot his wife in the head, he needs to get himself all worked up. Willy stares at the grainy black-and-white figure emerging from the room, walking away down the corridor. Unconvinced:
answer: Yeah. Worked up. Marchand gets his jacket, pulls it on.

question: You okay?
answer: Yeah. Maybe. Can I ask you to do something for me this morning?

question: Sure.
answer: Write down your cell number. Once my trial is in session, wait outside. I might call - and just hang up. If I do, I want you to come into court and whisper to me that we got a tip about the murder weapon.

question: You found it? Beat.
answer: I haven't decided yet. Mona studies Willy - then accepts it's don't-ask-don't-tell, hands him her number. Willy nods, grateful. Turning for the door, she remembers the envelope in her hand.

question: Oh
answer: So - between the time you heard the first gunshot and called 911, and the time of Mr. Crawford's arrest - you had the Crawford house in view?

question: So - between the time you heard the first gunshot and called 911, and the time of Mr. Crawford's arrest - you had the Crawford house in view?
answer: Yes. I was very concerned about Jennifer. She was a lovely woman.

question: No one but Thomas Crawford came in or out?
answer: That's correct.

question: Did you see the guy run out the back door?
answer: What..."guy"?

question: The other guy. The one who shot my wife. Did you see him run out the back of the house, carrying the gun? Willy closes his eyes. Gifford grimaces.
answer: I couldn't see the back of the house. I believe...the police went around back when they arrived.

question: Hey, you.
answer: Hey.

question: What did you think - I wasn't keeping tabs?
answer: I don't know what I thought. Awkward silence. She tries to get past it:

question: Listen
answer: Hang on - We move with Willy as he shuts the phone and heads for the doors - faster, pushing out - Your husband said something...that I can't seem to shake loose of. He said I'm a winner. And he's right. I can't lose. I can't stand people who lose. I may have been working so hard to put some distance between me and...people like you - that maybe I messed up. I don't know if did anything wrong. Or what I should have done. I really don't know, any more...what I'm supposed to do. But I feel like I let you down. Somehow in the...process. And if I did, I'm sorry. That's all. I just - I hope you...have...just, some... Anyway. He feels stupid. Takes a breath. Looking at her pale, drawn, comatose face. He stands, goes to get his jacket, lying folded on a table by the door. Pulls it on, settles the shoulders, tugs at his cuffs. Gets his briefcase. She was looking at me.

question: She's reacting. The Resident ignores him. Pricks her forehead - her chin - her big toe. Each time she twitches. He runs his thumb along the sole of Jennifer's bare foot. It arches up. You see?
answer: The normal reflex goes downward. Up indicates brain trauma.

question: She's in there. She was looking at me.
answer: Sometimes we have to tape their eyes shut. They all move - they make sounds, they twitch. You think they're dreaming. But they're not. It's just what's left of the system, sending broken signals.

question: Can we do other tests? Like an M.R.I. or something? And I want a coma specialist to see her.
answer: You're not authorized to order tes-

question: I'll get you authorization. First thing tomorrow. The Resident studies Willy. Reluctantly:
answer: You get the paperwork, I'll do what I can. Willy nods, grateful. As the Resident heads out, Willy sits by Jennifer's bed - protective, intent.

question: Mr. Slocum.
answer: Just...visiting.

question: This isn't like you at all.
answer: No?

question: You haven't got anything to gain.
answer: Oh - right. That's my weak spot. Ever think about what yours might be? Your flaw?

question: Of course I have. The truth about me is, Willy...I'm really not very nice. Willy nods. Concealing the ace up his sleeve.
answer: You sure do know a lot, though. Got everybody all figured out, everything set up, like one of your contraptions. Then you just sit back and watch it all fall right where you want it to. Must be kind of...boring. At that point.

question: Not an ounce of sympathy, Willy? Imagine it - imagine she was yours. And you knew you were losing her. Imagine days. Weeks. Going through her desk. Her purse. Her closet. Alone. Staring at her clothes. Her shoes. Knowing this is what it will be like. After. Do you have any idea how hard it was to go on living - with her - every day, knowing?
answer: But you had to, right? You needed time to set it all up...your "crime of passion."

question: There are many kinds of passion, Willy.
answer: Yeah. There are. So - thank you. Crawford frowns. Starting to feel wary. Willy sees it. Enjoys it. For sharing your wisdom. All your little helpful bits of information. You were right.

question: About...?
answer: Talking to her. Beat. Willy winks. He goes past Crawford and out the doors. Crawford doesn't move - except to turn and watch Willy. Uncertain, for the first time since we've met him. Hi, I'm just - - going directly to the key-card slot by the glass double- doors to the rest of the floor. He swipes his card and pulls the handle - - but it stays locked. Willy swipes his card again. No go. Excuse me - I'm new, I just started - and there's something wrong with my card. Can you buzz me in? I work here. Willy Slocum. I'm new - He stops, realizing how he must look. Nikki Gardner. Willy Slocum, for Nikki Gardner. As he calls in, Willy sees Nikki through the doors - one of a half-dozen ASSOCIATES trailing in the wake of BOB WOOTON. They all carry expensive business luggage, except Wooton - who is powerful, perfectly groomed, and two decades older. Wait a second - never mind, here she is, thank you. Willy goes toward the glass doors as Wooton comes through - nodding deferentially to the boss, semi-apologetic: Hey...Bob - Can I talk to you for a second? Wooton glances back at Nikki, eyes saying You let him know what happened last night?

question: Talking to her. Beat. Willy winks. He goes past Crawford and out the doors. Crawford doesn't move - except to turn and watch Willy. Uncertain, for the first time since we've met him. Hi, I'm just - - going directly to the key-card slot by the glass double- doors to the rest of the floor. He swipes his card and pulls the handle - - but it stays locked. Willy swipes his card again. No go. Excuse me - I'm new, I just started - and there's something wrong with my card. Can you buzz me in? I work here. Willy Slocum. I'm new - He stops, realizing how he must look. Nikki Gardner. Willy Slocum, for Nikki Gardner. As he calls in, Willy sees Nikki through the doors - one of a half-dozen ASSOCIATES trailing in the wake of BOB WOOTON. They all carry expensive business luggage, except Wooton - who is powerful, perfectly groomed, and two decades older. Wait a second - never mind, here she is, thank you. Willy goes toward the glass doors as Wooton comes through - nodding deferentially to the boss, semi-apologetic: Hey...Bob - Can I talk to you for a second? Wooton glances back at Nikki, eyes saying You let him know what happened last night?
answer: I told him.

question: Great - who do I work with on it while you're gone?
answer: You don't work with anyone.

question: Nikki
answer: Jesus, Willy, wake up! It's over! What is wrong with you - it's first year law

question: I told you - we bring a civil suit -
answer: You've got no standing.

question: It doesn't have to stick
answer: What's the point, Willy?

question: The point?! Willy stares. Because she's drawn a line in the sand. One he already crossed, without truly understanding...and now he's standing out there alone - feeling the sand slither away under his feet. This man is going to kill his wife.
answer: Yeah. What does that have to do with Wooton Sims? Willy just breathes. Vulnerable like we have never seen him before. He looks across the big reception area, at Wooton and the team of associates. Some look away. I warned you.

question: No, this is insane.
answer: It's what it is. I warned you. She starts for the elevators, Willy following -

question: You're not really just gonna let this happen, are you?!
answer: Oh I'm supposed to lose my job over your problems?!

question: My problems?! Wait a second - this is not about my anything any more - Willy grabs Nikki's arm to stop her, turn her around - and she shoves him away, hard, tears welling in her eyes - - Willy letting her go - as the Receptionist quietly calls for help - - and Nikki hurries into the waiting elevator. The Associate holding the doors lets them go. This is about taking a couple of goddamn weeks off to try and save a woman's life! The doors begin to close. Willy stands facing the cluster of lawyers in expensive suits, their expressions ranging from pity to contempt - - except Nikki, whose eyes are full of shame and guilt and defensive anger. As the doors shut across them. Willy doesn't move. Confused, humiliated, frustrated. He turns when a bunch of OTHER LAWYERS emerge from the offices, ready to act as bouncers. People gawk from behind the glass doors. Beat. Willy holds up his palms. Don't bother. I got it.
answer: What do the doctors say?

question: People wake up out of these things.
answer: What did the doctors say, Mr. Slocum?

question: They said...there's no way to really know. I'm trying to get them to run more tests - but I was there, and I'm telling you.
answer: I'm sorry. I have no probable cause to issue a court order against Mr. Crawford - and he's protected agai-

question: WHAT ABOUT HIS WIFE?! WHAT'S I'm sorry - but nobody else seems to give a damn that sooner or later this guy is gonna finish what he started. Beat.
answer: Have you been home at all today, Willy?

question: No - I've been trying to get some-
answer: There's a court order out against you.

question: What?
answer: A restraining order. You were at the hospital? Talking to her doctors? Willy nods. Lobruto looks out at the confused, frantic young man - truly sorry that he can't help Willy fight his way back toward doing some good in this mess. Crawford hired a lawyer this time. They saw Judge Gorman this afternoon.

question: Against me.
answer: You need to stay away from him, and his wife, and the hospital. He can have you arrested if you don't. I'm sorry. I can't help you. I told you how it would go. Willy stares a second, slowly understanding his situation.

question: Can you do anything for her? Beat.
answer: I don't see how. Willy grimaces. But nods. Turns away.

question: What? How long ago...did she die? He's - moving her by helicopter? Then just hold it - for a couple of hours! Have it inspected! She's not gonna get there! He looks at Crawford This man is a mechanical engineer with expertise in air crashes! He has access to airfields and he knows exactly how to make it look like an accident! You know what he did! You know why she's like this! Lunt hesitates, feeling a tiny edge of doubt. Crawford checks his watch. Looks into Willy's eyes - - then gestures for Willy to join him, and turns back to walk across the pad to the helicopter. Climbs in. Willy stares, stunned. Lunt looks at him Why are we going out over the ocean?
answer: Less traffic. Willy looks at Crawford.

question: We have to turn back!
answer: Get in your seat!

question: He's doing something - we have to turn back!
answer: Who's doing something? Willy points to Crawford, who's just sitting there -

question: He is! You have to get us DOWN!
answer: Get back in your goddamn seat!

question: Willy, I'm not doing anything. Everyone can see that.
answer: I'm TELLING you, we have to TURN BACK! He's DOING SOMETH- An alarm begins to shriek - on the ventilator. Everyone turns as the Med Tech hastily kneels next to it - What's happening?!

question: She's D.N.R. The Med Tech looks up - startled. Confused.
answer: What is it?

question: Check. Willy watches, wide-eyed, as the Med Tech grabs up his paperwork, searching it -
answer: What? The Med Tech looks up at Willy, scared.

question: It's in her living will. The Med Tech looks at Willy, paralyzed.
answer: There's a restraining order - she's protected - I'm authorizing you to do it! The Med Tech turns to Crawford, uncertain -

question: You're not answering your phone. Beat.
answer: That's kind of an answer in itself, isn't it? Willy heads back in, starts to pack again.

question: Where are you headed?
answer: Haven't decided yet. Just someplace else. Lobruto nods. Willy packs.

question: I shouldn't have let it get so far out of control. We all lose, Willy.
answer: Yep.

question: We just have to live with that, and keep fighting the good fight.
answer: That's not what I was doing.

question: You belong in a courtroom. Willy packs, thinking about that. Shakes his head.
answer: I need to - get to know myself better.

question: You're a good lawyer. All this may have even made you a better lawyer. Don't waste it. Willy turns on him - angry, confused, bitter:
answer: I didn't just lose a case! I let a man get away with murder. Lobruto nods. Respecting his pain. Shrugs, accepts the decision, with regret. Willy nods his thanks, and turns back to packing. Lobruto starts to leave. But from the alley door:

question: If it makes you feel any better - technically, you let a man get away with attempted murder. Willy doesn't respond. Keeps packing. Lobruto goes out. After a moment, Willy stops. Looking up. Something turning over in his mind.
answer: His wife is dead! Lobruto turns. Uncertain what Willy is getting at. We can still get him. We can take him back to court.

question: Willy... Willy comes toward him - excited, insistent:
answer: Double jeopardy doesn't apply! We bring a new charge - of homicide.

question: Willy - what happened to you, on the helicopter - we don't even know if we could prove -
answer: No

question: A second indictment on the same incident?
answer: A man burns down a house; we charge him with arson. There were people sleeping upstairs - and after weeks in the hospital, they die. We'd charge him with murder. Right? Lobruto nods. On the fence, but seeing it now. Impressed with the young man's fervor, and his logic. But he shakes his head.

question: All your evidence is still toxic. The confession, the arrest - it's all still inadmissible. Willy grimaces. Looks down. Thinking, intense. I'm sorry, Willy. It was a good idea, but -
answer: I'll get something new.

question: How? Willy looks up at him. Calm now.
answer: You don't want to know.

question: Willy, you can't -
answer: I don't work for you. Right? Beat. Lobruto sighs, as Willy nods and turns to start back to the garage. With work to do.

question: Don't do anything crazy.
answer: What else have we got left? Willy disappears inside. I need a favor.

question: What else have we got left? Willy disappears inside. I need a favor.
answer: These are from that thing at the courthouse, right?

question: Uh-huh. The Clerk stops, checking a number against a slip of paper in his hand - pulls down a box for Willy.
answer: Very dramatic. Willy crosses the room to the alarm panel on the wall.

question: You ain't seen nothin' yet. He presses the POLICE emergency button, then turns to Crawford. I want the gun.
answer: Why? You've already got one.

question: I want the gun you shot your wife with. Now. Crawford doesn't move. Willy raises his gun, points it at Crawford's face. One way or another, I'm going to see to it you receive justice tonight. Crawford studies Willy.
answer: You're serious, aren't you.

question: Oh, yes.
answer: Willy. You got religion, didn't you?! You care. That's...priceless. He laughs. Willy keeps the gun aimed at him. No, it's very sweet. Really.

question: Gonna be a whole lot less funny in about a minute. Crawford nods. Considering the game. Unruffled.
answer: Getting it like this

question: I don't work for the D.A. any more. I'm just a guy who broke into your house. When the police arrest me - they'll inventory anything in my possession. If that happens to be crucial evidence in another case, well
answer: It takes a very special kind of person to look right into someone's eyes and pull the trigger. It takes a unique kind of strength.

question: I guess you'd know that.
answer: Yes. I would. Willy cocks the gun. Crawford shakes his head. Eyes on Willy. I don't think so. Willy doesn't lower the gun. But he doesn't pull the trigger, either.

question: You don't know me.
answer: No? Then I'm in for a - rude awakening. Willy glares over the gun. Crawford shrugs. Tick-tock. Willy's angry. Frustrated. Trapped. His bluff called. Refusing to back down. Where did you even get yourself a gun?

question: It's Nunally's. Crawford is thrown by this - but conceals it well.
answer: Nunally's. Really. Willy grimaces, over the gun still aimed at Crawford's face.

question: Yeah. Really. He has backed himself into a corner, and he's getting scared. Because all of a sudden the threat he came to fake Crawford out with - - is starting to seem like his only way out. Even Crawford sees it. In Willy's eyes. The uncertain edge of the idea. He could just do it. End the game. Blow Crawford's brains all over the wall. There I was, with a perfectly good weapon just sitting in the evidence warehouse. It would be so easy. With his life already a shambles. With everything already lost. At least he would have this.
answer: Willy. Put it down.

question: I thought you might appreciate the ...irony. Willy's finger tightens on the trigger.
answer: Willy. Think. And Willy does. Hesitating. Distracted, by a thought. Lowering the gun slightly, looking at it - remembering:
